context: Pyrolytic degradation in the cavitational bubble took place at low pH values, due to hydrophobic interaction. Ultrasonic degradation of trichloroethylene (TCE) at millimolar concentration levels at a frequency of 520 kHz, proved that the degradation did not occur in the bulk solution. From the analysis of the volatile organic intermediates, it was concluded that the products were typically pyrolysis products, confirming the hot spot theory and showing that TCE was predominantly degraded by pyrolysis, rather than by OH or H radical induced degradation pathways. Similar degradation pathways were observed for chlorobenzene (CB) at millimolar concentration levels. Addition of the radical scavenger, benzoate, demonstrated that no significant degradation took place in the bulk solution. The fact that chlorophenols were detected as intermediates, only if the solution was air saturated and not if argon saturated, proved that these intermediate products were not generated by OH radical induced degradation mechanisms, but by reactions of intermediates with oxygen. De Visscher et al. confirmed that pyrolysis is the dominating degradation mechanism at millimolar concentrations, by fitting experimental results into a model, based on first-order pyrolysis kinetics.

The detection of chlorophenols as intermediates further supports the specific degradation route of chlorobenzene under certain conditions, emphasizing its chemical behavior in environmental degradation studies.
